en.title: Divorce application (petition)
en.divorceRoleExplain: The applicant is the person who has applied for a divorce (legally known as the petitioner). The respondent is their husband or wife.
en.coRespRoleExplain: The co-respondent is the person the applicant claims the respondent committed adultery with.
en.whoTheMarriageNames: {{ session.originalPetition.marriagePetitionerName }} and {{ session.originalPetition.marriageRespondentName }} (as shown on the marriage certificate)
en.marriageDetailsExplained: These details are copied exactly from the marriage certificate, or a translation of the certificate if it's not in English. The names on the certificate are the names that the applicant and respondent used before the marriage.
en.whyTheCourtHeading: Why the court can deal with the case (jurisdiction)
en.theCourtsOfEngland: The courts of England and Wales must have the jurisdiction (the legal power) to be able to grant a divorce. The applicant confirmed that the legal statement, or statements, given in the application apply to either, or both the applicant and respondent.
en.eachLegalStatement: Each legal statement includes some or all of the following legal connections to England and Wales.
en.habitualResidencePar1: If your lives are mainly based in England or Wales then you're what is legally known as 'habitually resident'.
en.habitualResidencePar2: This may include working, owning property, having children in school, and your main family life taking place in England or Wales.
en.habitualResidencePar3: The examples above aren't a complete list of what makes up habitual residence, and just because some of them apply to you doesn’t mean you’re habitually resident. If you’re not sure, you should get legal advice.
en.domicilePar1: Your domicile is usually the place in which you were born, regard as your permanent home and to which you have the closest ties.
en.domicilePar2: However, domicile can be more complex if you or your parents have moved countries in the past.
en.domicilePar3: When you're born, you acquire a domicile of origin. This is usually:
en.domicileList1: the country your father considered his permanent home if your parents were married
en.domicileList2: the country your mother considered her permanent home if your parents were unmarried, or your father had died
en.domicilePar4: If you leave your domicile of origin and settle in another country as an adult, the new country may become your domicile of choice.
en.domicilePar5: If you're not sure about your domicile you should get legal advice.
en.residualJurisdictionPar1: The court may have residual jurisdiction if none of the other connections apply, and both of the following are true:
en.residualJurisdictionList2: either the applicant (petitioner) or the respondent is domiciled in England or Wales
en.residualJurisdictionList3: neither the applicant nor the respondent is able to apply (on the basis of their nationality or residence) for a divorce in another member state of the EU
en.residualJurisdictionPar2: In addition, if the marriage is between a same-sex couple, the court may have residual jurisdiction if all the following apply:
en.residualJurisdictionList4: the applicant and the respondent married each other in England or Wales
en.residualJurisdictionList5: neither the applicant nor the respondent is able to apply for a divorce in any other country
en.residualJurisdictionList6: it would be in the interests of justice for the court to consider the application (for example, this may apply if the applicant’s or respondent’s home country doesn’t allow divorce between same-sex couples).
en.otherCourtCasesPar1: The court needs to know if there any other court cases which might affect the jurisdiction of the court, and its decision to grant a divorce.
en.reasonForDivorcePar1: The only legal ground for divorce in England and Wales is if the marriage has broken down irretrievably.
en.reasonForDivorcePar2: The applicant had to choose a reason for the breakdown of the marriage (legally known as the 'fact') from the following list.
en.behaviourParagraph1: The respondent has behaved in such a way that the applicant cannot reasonably be expected to live with them.
en.behaviourParagraph2: The applicant must provide enough examples of the respondent's behaviour to satisfy the court that they can't reasonably be expected to live with them. The examples must be of the respondent's behaviour, and examples where the applicant and respondent are both at fault cannot be used.
en.behaviourParagraph3: If the applicant lives with the respondent as a couple for more than 6 months after the most recent example of behaviour, the court will take this into account in its judgement of whether or not the marriage has broken down irretrievably. This could be over a single 6 month period, or if they live together on and off for several periods adding up to more than 6 months.
en.adulteryParagraph1: The respondent committed adultery, and the applicant finds it intolerable to live with them.
en.adulteryParagraph2: Adultery can only be used if it was with a member of the opposite sex.
en.adulteryParagraph3: The applicant has the option of naming the person with whom the respondent committed adultery (known as the co-respondent). Co-respondents are sent a copy of the divorce application and asked if they want to defend the allegations.
en.adulteryParagraph4: Adultery can't be used as a reason if the applicant and respondent lived together as a couple for more than 6 months after the applicant found out about it. This could have been in one go, or if they lived together on and off for several periods of time adding up to more than 6 months.
en.separatedFor2YearsParagraph1: The applicant and respondent must have spent the past 2 years living apart to use this reason for divorce.
en.separatedFor2YearsParagraph2: They are allowed to have spent some time living together, but only for up to 6 months (over one or more periods) and this time doesn’t count towards the 2 year period. They’ll need to have lived apart for longer to make up any time that they spent living together.
en.separatedFor2YearsParagraph3: The respondent must give their consent to a divorce for this reason to be used.
en.separatedFor5YearsParagraph1: The applicant and respondent must have spent the past 5 years living apart to use this reason for divorce.
en.separatedFor5YearsParagraph2: They are allowed to have spent some time living together, but only for up to 6 months (over one or more periods) and this time doesn’t count towards the 5 year period. They’ll need to have lived apart for longer to make up any time that they spent living together.
en.desertionParagraph1: The respondent left the applicant without their agreement at least 2 years ago, and they have lived apart since.
en.desertionParagraph2: The applicant and respondent are allowed to have spent some time living together since the desertion, but only for up to 6 months (over one or more periods) and this time doesn’t count towards the 2 year period. They’ll need to have lived apart for longer to make up any time that they spent living together.
en.desertionParagraph3: The respondent must have chosen to leave the applicant. For example, it can't be used if they have been sent to prison.
en.claimingCostsPar1: Your {{ session.divorceWho }} was asked if they want the court to order you to pay some or all of the divorce costs. If your {{ session.divorceWho }} is using adultery as the reason for divorce and has chosen to name the co-respondent, they can also be asked to pay for some of the costs.
en.claimingCostsPar2: This could include all the fees during the divorce, such as the £{{ feesIssueApplication }} application fee, solicitor fees, and any extra court fees.
en.helpWithFinancialOrdersPar1: Your {{ session.divorceWho }} was asked if they want the court to decide how your property, money, pensions and other assets will be split.
en.helpWithFinancialOrdersPar2: These decisions are called 'financial orders'. Financial orders can be made between you and your {{ session.divorceWho }} and for any children you may have.
en.helpWithFinancialOrdersPar3: To formally start legal proceedings, your {{ session.divorceWho }} will need to complete another form (known as Form A) and pay a fee of £{{ feesDivorceSubmitFormA }}. This means that they don't have to proceed with the financial order at this point.
en.consentOrdersPar1: If you both agree on how to split your money and property and want to make it legally binding, you can apply for a type of financial order called a 'consent order'.
en.consentOrdersPar2: You'll need to get a solicitor to draft the consent order, and then send it to the court with a £{{ feesFinancialConsentOrder }} fee.
en.consentOrdersPar3: You should get legal advice if you're not sure what to do.
en.ordersForChildMaintenancePar: The court can only make financial orders for children under certain circumstances. You'll usually either need to come to an agreement with your {{ session.divorceWho }} (which you can then make legally binding with a consent order) or use the Child Maintenance Service.

en.jurisdictionConnectionBothResident: The applicant and respondent are both ‘habitually resident’ in England and Wales.
en.jurisdictionConnectionBothDomiciled: The applicant and respondent are both domiciled in England and Wales.
en.jurisdictionConnectionOneResides: The applicant and respondent were last habitually resident in England and Wales and one of them still resides there.
en.jurisdictionConnectionPetitioner: The applicant is habitually resident in England and Wales and has resided there for at least a year immediately prior to the presentation of the application.
en.jurisdictionConnectionRespondent: The respondent is habitually resident in England and Wales.
en.jurisdictionConnectionPetitionerSixMonth: The applicant is domiciled and habitually resident in England and Wales and has resided there for at least six months immediately prior to the application.
en.jurisdictionConnectionOther: The courts of England and Wales have residual jurisdiction.
en.otherCourtCases: Other court cases that could affect jurisdiction
en.onGoingCasesNo: There are no other ongoing, completed or abandoned court cases related to the marriage, property or children.
en.onGoingCasesYes: The applicant has given the following court cases which are related to the marriage, property or children.
